        <gmd:MD_DataIdentification id="DataIdentification">
            <gmd:citation>
                <gmd:CI_Citation>

                            </gmd:code>

                    </gmd:identifier>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                            <gmd:organisationName>
                                <gco:CharacterString>FortWhyte Alive</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="author">author

                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                            <gmd:organisationName>
                                <gco:CharacterString>FortWhyte Alive</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="contributor">contributor
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                </gmd:CI_Citation>
            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>FortWhyte Alive, 1961 McCreary Rd. in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, is more than just a nature centre, wildlife refuge, or a place for education – our 640 acres of protected urban greenspace is an award-winning destination for incredible outdoor experiences.

Mission: FortWhyte Alive is dedicated to providing programming, natural settings and facilities for environmental education, outdoor recreation and social enterprise. In so doing, FortWhyte promotes awareness and understanding of the natural world and actions leading to sustainable living.

FortWhyte Alive is located on a reclaimed industrial site, developed as a clay-pit quarry by Canada Cement in 1911. Five lakes were excavated as a part of this process. Since 1967, our private, non-profit organization has been offering educational programming onsite, including urban fishing and non-motorized recreational use of our lakes including sailing, canoeing and swimming. The lakes are considered a closed-system watershed, with infrequent water quantity contributions from overland flooding. 

Declining water quality conditions and large fluctuations in water quantity in FortWhyte Alive's lakes has been identified through staff observations and the completion of a North-South Consultants Assessment of Current Water Quality Conditions in August 2009. In 2013, FortWhyte staff began to collect monthly baseline monitoring data on lake health parameters, year-round, and continue to current time. The program's purpose is to provide a data source for open access by researchers, and to assist in the organization’s water management decisions, with the goal of preventing further eutrophication and improving water quality parameters. FortWhyte Alive engages an Aquatic Advisory Board of aquatic research experts to advise us on monitoring actions.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>
            <gmd:credit gco:nilReason="missing"/>

                codeListValue="onGoing">onGoing</gmd:MD_ProgressCode>

            </gmd:resourceConstraints>

                <gco:CharacterString>eng</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:language>

                <gmd:MD_TopicCategoryCode>inlandWaters</gmd:MD_TopicCategoryCode>
            </gmd:topicCategory>

                        <gmd:EX_GeographicBoundingBox>
                            <gmd:extentTypeCode>
                                <gco:Boolean>1</gco:Boolean>
                            </gmd:extentTypeCode>
                            <gmd:westBoundLongitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>-97.22875</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:westBoundLongitude>
                            <gmd:eastBoundLongitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>-97.21937</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:eastBoundLongitude>

                    <gmd:temporalElement>

                                <gml:TimePeriod gml:id="TimePeriod">
                                    <gml:description>seconds</gml:description>
                                    <gml:beginPosition>2013-03-20T00:00:00+00:00</gml:beginPosition>
                                    <gml:endPosition>2023-01-13T00:00:00+00:00</gml:endPosition>

name: 10-25976-h30w-an19
notes:
FortWhyte Alive, 1961 McCreary Rd. in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, is more than just a nature centre, wildlife refuge, or a place for education – our 640 acres of protected urban greenspace is an award-winning destination for incredible outdoor experiences.

Mission: FortWhyte Alive is dedicated to providing programming, natural settings and facilities for environmental education, outdoor recreation and social enterprise. In so doing, FortWhyte promotes awareness and understanding of the natural world and actions leading to sustainable living.

FortWhyte Alive is located on a reclaimed industrial site, developed as a clay-pit quarry by Canada Cement in 1911. Five lakes were excavated as a part of this process. Since 1967, our private, non-profit organization has been offering educational programming onsite, including urban fishing and non-motorized recreational use of our lakes including sailing, canoeing and swimming. The lakes are considered a closed-system watershed, with infrequent water quantity contributions from overland flooding. 

Declining water quality conditions and large fluctuations in water quantity in FortWhyte Alive's lakes has been identified through staff observations and the completion of a North-South Consultants Assessment of Current Water Quality Conditions in August 2009. In 2013, FortWhyte staff began to collect monthly baseline monitoring data on lake health parameters, year-round, and continue to current time. The program's purpose is to provide a data source for open access by researchers, and to assist in the organization’s water management decisions, with the goal of preventing further eutrophication and improving water quality parameters. FortWhyte Alive engages an Aquatic Advisory Board of aquatic research experts to advise us on monitoring actions.

notes_translated.en:
FortWhyte Alive, 1961 McCreary Rd. in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, is more than just a nature centre, wildlife refuge, or a place for education – our 640 acres of protected urban greenspace is an award-winning destination for incredible outdoor experiences.

Mission: FortWhyte Alive is dedicated to providing programming, natural settings and facilities for environmental education, outdoor recreation and social enterprise. In so doing, FortWhyte promotes awareness and understanding of the natural world and actions leading to sustainable living.

FortWhyte Alive is located on a reclaimed industrial site, developed as a clay-pit quarry by Canada Cement in 1911. Five lakes were excavated as a part of this process. Since 1967, our private, non-profit organization has been offering educational programming onsite, including urban fishing and non-motorized recreational use of our lakes including sailing, canoeing and swimming. The lakes are considered a closed-system watershed, with infrequent water quantity contributions from overland flooding. 

Declining water quality conditions and large fluctuations in water quantity in FortWhyte Alive's lakes has been identified through staff observations and the completion of a North-South Consultants Assessment of Current Water Quality Conditions in August 2009. In 2013, FortWhyte staff began to collect monthly baseline monitoring data on lake health parameters, year-round, and continue to current time. The program's purpose is to provide a data source for open access by researchers, and to assist in the organization’s water management decisions, with the goal of preventing further eutrophication and improving water quality parameters. FortWhyte Alive engages an Aquatic Advisory Board of aquatic research experts to advise us on monitoring actions.
notes_translated.fr:
FortWhyte Alive, 1961 McCreary Rd. à Winnipeg, au Manitoba, au Canada, est bien plus qu'un simple centre naturel, un refuge faunique ou un lieu d'enseignement : nos 640 acres d'espaces verts urbains protégés sont une destination primée pour des expériences de plein air incroyables.

Mission : FortWhyte Alive se consacre à fournir des programmes, des environnements naturels et des installations pour l'éducation environnementale, les loisirs de plein air et les entreprises sociales. Ce faisant, FortWhyte favorise la prise de conscience et la compréhension du monde naturel et des actions menant à un mode de vie durable.

FortWhyte Alive est situé sur un site industriel récupéré, développé comme carrière d'argile par Canada Cement en 1911. Cinq lacs ont été excavés dans le cadre de ce processus. Depuis 1967, notre organisation privée à but non lucratif propose des programmes éducatifs sur place, notamment la pêche urbaine et l'utilisation récréative non motorisée de nos lacs, notamment la voile, le canotage et la natation. Les lacs sont considérés comme un bassin versant en réseau fermé, les inondations de surface contribuant peu fréquemment à la quantité d'eau. 

La détérioration de la qualité de l'eau et les fortes fluctuations de la quantité d'eau dans les lacs de FortWhyte Alive ont été identifiées grâce aux observations du personnel et à la réalisation d'une évaluation nord-sud des conditions actuelles de qualité de l'eau par des consultants en août 2009. En 2013, le personnel de FortWhyte a commencé à recueillir des données de surveillance de référence mensuelles sur les paramètres de santé des lacs, tout au long de l'année, et ce, jusqu'à aujourd'hui. L'objectif du programme est de fournir une source de données accessible en libre accès aux chercheurs et d'aider l'organisation à prendre des décisions en matière de gestion de l'eau, dans le but de prévenir une nouvelle eutrophisation et d'améliorer les paramètres de qualité de l'eau. FortWhyte Alive fait appel à un conseil consultatif composé d'experts en recherche aquatique pour nous conseiller sur les mesures de surveillance.

notes_translation_method.fr: Description text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.

title_translated.fr: Projet de bassin versant de Fort-Whyte Alive
